ZPLCommand.Name: ^A
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^A command specifies the font to use in a text field. ^A designates the font for the current ^FD statement or field.\r\nThe font specified by ^A is used only once for that ^FD entry.\r\nIf a value for ^A is not specified again, the default ^CF font is used for the next ^FD entry.

TextBox.Name: f
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any font in the printer (downloaded, EPROM, stored fonts, fonts A through Z and 0 to 9).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^A@
ZPLCommand.ShortDesc: Use Font Name to Call Font
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^A@ command uses the complete name of a font, rather than the character designation used in ^A.\r\nOnce a value for ^A@ is defined, it represents that font until a new font name is specified by ^A@.

TextBox.Name: n
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any valid font.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B0
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B0 command creates a two-dimensional matrix symbology made up of square modules arranged around a bulls-eye pattern at the center.

NumericBox.Name: b
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: 1 to 10 (1 on 150 dpi printers - 2 on 200 dpi printers - 3 on 300 dpi printers - 6 on 600 dpi printers).

NumericBox.Name: d
NumericBox.Description: Error ctrl and symbol size/type ID
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: 0 = default error correction level - 01 to 99 = error correction percentage (minimum) - 101 to 104 = 1 to 4-layer compact symbol - 201 to 232 = 1 to 32-layer full-range symbol - 300 = a simple Aztec ''Rune''.

ComboBoxValues.ComboBoxValue: this symbol is to be a menu (bar code reader initialization) symbol
it is not a menu symbol

NumericBox.Name: f
NumericBox.Description: Number of symbols for structured append

TextBox.Name: g
TextBox.Description: Optional ID field for structured append
TextBox.AcceptedValue: The ID field is a text string with 24-character maximum.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B1
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B1 command produces the Code 11 bar code, also known as USD-8 code. In a Code 11 bar code, each character is composed of three bars and two spaces, and the character set includes 10 digits and the hyphen (-)

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B2
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B2 command produces the Interleaved 2 of 5 bar code, a high-density, self-checking, continuous, numeric symbology.

ComboBox.Name: e
ComboBox.Description: Calc. and print mod10 check digit

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B3
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The Code 39 bar code is the standard for many industries, including the U.S. Department of Defense. It is one of three symbologies identified in the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) standard MH10.8M-1983. Code 39 is also known as USD-3 Code and 3 of 9 Code.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B4
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B4 command creates a multi-row, continuous, variable-length symbology capable of encoding the full 128-character ASCII set. It is ideally suited for applications requiring large amounts of data in a small space.\r\nThe code consists of two to eight rows. A row consists of a leading quiet zone, four symbol characters encoding eight code characters, a stop pattern, and a trailing quiet zone. A separator bar with a height of one module separates each row. Each symbol character encodes two characters from a set of Code 49 characters

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B5
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B5 command is supported in all printers as a resident bar code.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B7
ZPLCommand.LongDesc:
The ^B7 command produces the PDF417 bar code, a two-dimensional, multirow, continuous, stacked symbology. PDF417 is capable of encoding over 1,000 characters per bar code. It is ideally suited for applications requiring large amounts of information at the time the bar code is read.
The bar code consists of three to 90 stacked rows. Each row consists of start and stop patterns and symbol characters called code-words. A code-word consists of four bars and four spaces.
A three code-word minimum is required per row.
The PDF417 bar code is also capable of using the structured append option (^FM), which allows you to extend the field data limitations by printing multiple bar codes. For more information on using structured append, see ^FM.

NumericBox.Name: h
NumericBox.Description: Bar code height for individual rows

NumericBox.Name: c
NumericBox.Description: Number of data columns to encode

ComboBox.Name: t
ComboBox.Description: Truncate right row ID and stop pattern

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B8
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B8 command produces the EAN8 bar code, a shortened version of the EAN-13 bar code.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^B9
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^B9 command produces a variation of the UPC symbology used for number system 0. It is a shortened version of the UPC-A bar code, where zeros are suppressed, resulting in codes that require less printing space. The 6 dot/mm, 12 dot/mm, and 24 dot/mm printheads produce the UPC and EAN symbologies at 100 percent of their size. However, an 8 dot/mm printhead produces the UPC and EAN symbologies at a magnification factor of 77 percent.\r\nEach character in a UPC-E bar code is composed of four elements: two bars and two spaces. The ^BY command must be used to specify the width of the narrow bar.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BA
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BA command creates a variable length, continuous symbology. The Code 93 bar code is used in many of the same applications as Code 39. It uses the full 128-character ASCII set. ZPL II, however, does not support ASCII control codes or escape sequences. It uses the substitute characters shown in ZPL User Guide P74

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BB
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BB command produces a two-dimensional, multirow, stacked symbology. It is ideally suited for applications that require large amounts of information.Depending on the mode selected, the code consists of one to 44 stacked rows. Each row begins and ends with a start and stop pattern.\r\n- CODABLOCK A supports variable print ratios.\r\n- CODABLOCK E and F support only fixed print ratios.

NumericBox.Name: r
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: 1 to 22: CODABLOCK A - 2 to 4: CODABLOCK E and F

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BC
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BC command creates the Code 128 bar code, a high-density, variable length, continuous, alphanumeric symbology. It was designed for complexly encoded product identification.\r\nCode 128 has three subsets of characters. There are 106 encoded printing characters in each set, and each character can have up to three different meanings, depending on the character subset being used. Each Code 128 character consists of six elements: three bars and three spaces

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BD
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BD command creates a two-dimensional, optically read (not scanned) code. This symbology was developed by UPS (United Parcel Service).\r\nNotice that there are no additional parameters for this code and it does not generate an interpretation line. The ^BY command has no effect on the UPS MaxiCode bar code.\r\nHowever, the ^CV command can be activated.

ComboBoxValues.ComboBoxValue: Structured carrier message: numeric postal code (U.S.)
Structured carrier message: alphanumeric postal code (non-U.S.)

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BE
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BE command produces the EAN13 bar code. The EAN-13 bar code has 12 data characters, one more data character than the UPC-A code.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BF
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BF command creates a two-dimensional, multi-row, continuous, stacked symbology identical to PDF417, except it replaces the 17-module-wide start and stop patterns and left/right row indicators with a unique set of 10-module-wide row address patterns. These reduce overall symbol width and allow linear scanning at row heights as low as 2X.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BI
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BI command is a discrete, self-checking, continuous numeric symbology. The Industrial 2 of 5 bar code has been in use the longest of the 2 of 5 family of bar codes. Of that family, the Standard 2 of 5 (^BJ) and Interleaved 2 of 5 (^B2) bar codes are also available in ZPL II.\r\nWith Industrial 2 of 5, all of the information is contained in the bars. Two bar widths are employed in this code, the wide bar measuring three times the width of the narrow bar.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BJ
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BJ command is a discrete, self-checking, continuous numeric symbology.\r\nWith Standard 2 of 5, all of the information is contained in the bars. Two bar widths are employed in this code, the wide bar measuring three times the width of the narrow bar.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BK
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ANSI Codabar bar code is used in a variety of information processing applications such as libraries, the medical industry, and overnight package delivery companies. This bar code is also known as USD-4 code, NW-7, and 2 of 7 code. It was originally developed for retail price labeling.\r\nEach character in this code is composed of seven elements: four bars and three spaces. Codabar bar codes use two character sets, numeric and control (start and stop) characters.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BL
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BL command is a special application of Code 39 used by the Department of Defense.\r\nLOGMARS is an acronym for Logistics Applications of Automated Marking and Reading Symbols.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BM
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BM command is a pulse-width modulated, continuous, non-self- checking symbology. It is a variant of the Plessey bar code (^BP).\r\nEach character in the MSI bar code is composed of eight elements: four bars and four adjacent spaces.

ComboBox.Name: e2
ComboBox.Description: Print check digit into the interpretation line

ArrayOfZPLCommand.ZPLCommand:
^BO Barcode Aztec Bar Code Parameters The ^BO command creates a two-dimensional matrix symbology made up of square modules arranged around a bulls-eye pattern at the center. ^BOa,b,c,d,e,f,g ^BO{{a}},{{b}},{{c}},{{d}},{{e}},{{f}},{{g}}> ^BO|a,b,c,d,e,f,g
Normal Rotated 90 degrees (clockwise) Inverted 180 degrees Read from bottom up, 270 degrees
Data contain ECICs Data does not contain ECICs
Symbol is a menu Symbol is not a menu

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BP
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BP command is a pulse-width modulated, continuous, non-self- checking symbology.\r\nEach character in the Plessey bar code is composed of eight elements: four bars and four adjacent spaces.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BQ
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BQ command produces a matrix symbology consisting of an array of nominally square modules arranged in an overall square pattern. A unique pattern at three of the symbolâ€™s four corners assists in determining bar code size, position, and inclination.\r\nA wide range of symbol sizes is possible, along with four levels of error correction. Userspecified module dimensions provide a wide variety of symbol production techniques.

NumericBox.Name: c
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: 1 to 10 (1 on 150 dpi printers - 2 on 200 dpi printers - 3 on 300 dpi printers - 6 on 600 dpi printers).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BR
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BR command is bar code types for space-constrained identification from EAN International and the Uniform Code Council, Inc.

NumericBox.Name: c
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: 1 to 10. 24 dot = 6, 12 dot is 3, 8 dot and lower is 2 - 12 dot = 6, > 8 dot is 3, 8 dot and less is 2

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BS
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BS command is the two-digit and five-digit add-on used primarily by publishers to create bar codes for ISBNs (International Standard Book Numbers). These extensions are handled as separate bar codes.\r\nThe ^BS command is designed to be used with the UPC-A bar code (^BU) and the UPC-E bar code (^B9).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BT
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BT bar code is the standard for the TCIF can tag telecommunications equipment.\r\nThe TCIF CLEI code, which is the MicroPDF417 bar code, is always four columns. The firmware must determine what mode to use based on the number of characters to be encoded.

NumericBox.Name: w1
NumericBox.Description: Width of the Code 39 bar code

NumericBox.Name: r1
NumericBox.Description: Wide to narrow bar width ratio the Code 39 bar code

NumericBox.Name: h1
NumericBox.Description: Height of the Code 39 bar code

NumericBox.Name: h2
NumericBox.Description: Row height of the MicroPDF417 bar code

NumericBox.Name: w2
NumericBox.Description: Narrow bar width of the MicroPDF417 bar code

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BU
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BU command produces the UPC-A bar code, a fixed length, numeric symbology.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BX
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BX command creates a two-dimensional matrix symbology made up of square modules arranged within a perimeter finder pattern.

NumericBox.Name: h
NumericBox.Description: Dimensional height of individual symbol elements
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From 1 to the width of the label

ComboBoxValues.ComboBoxValue: Uppercase alphanumeric + space, period, comma, dash, and slash (0..9,A..Z,â€œ.-/â€)

TextBox.Name: g
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any character

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BY
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^BY command is used to change the default values for the module width (in dots), the wide bar to narrow bar width ratio and the bar code height (in dots).\r\nIt can be used as often as necessary within a label format.

NumericBox.Name: r
NumericBox.Description: Wide bar to narrow bar width ratio

NumericBox.Name: h
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From 1 to the height of the label

ZPLCommand.Name: ^BZ
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The POSTAL bar code is used to automate the handling of mail. POSTAL codes use a series of tall and short bars to represent the digits.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^CF
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^CF command sets the default font used in your printer. You can use the ^CF command to simplify your programs.

TextBox.Name: f
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any font in the printer (downloaded, EPROM, stored fonts, fonts A through Z and 0 to 9).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^CI
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: Zebra printers can print fonts using international character sets: U.S.A.1, U.S.A.2, UK, Holland,Denmark/Norway, Sweden/Finland, Germany, France 1, France 2, Italy, Spain, and severalother sets, including the Unicode character set.\r\nThe ^CI command enables you to call up the international character set you want to use forprinting. You can mix character sets on a label.\r\nA character within a font can be remapped to a different numerical position.

ComboBoxValues.ComboBoxValue: Single Byte Encoding - U.S.A. 1 Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - U.S.A. 2 Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - U.K. Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Holland Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Denmark/Norway Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Sweden/Finland Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Germany Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - France 1 Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - France 2 Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Italy Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Spain Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Miscellaneous Character Set
Single Byte Encoding - Japan (ASCII with Yen symbol) Character Set
Multibyte Asian Encodings with ASCII Transparency
Unicode (UTF-16 Big-Endian encoding) - Unicode Character Set
Unicode (UTF-16 Little-Endian encoding) - Unicode Character Set

ZPLCommand.Name: ^CW
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: All built-in fonts are referenced using a one-character identifier. The ^CW command assigns a single alphanumeric character to a font stored in DRAM, memory card, EPROM, or Flash.\r\nIf the assigned character is the same as that of a built-in font, the downloaded font is used in place of the built-in font. The new font is printed on the label wherever the format calls for the built-in font. If used in place of a built-in font, the change is in effect only until power is turned off.

TextBox.Name: a
TextBox.Description: Letter of existing font to be substituted, or new font to be added
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any font in the printer (downloaded, EPROM, stored fonts, fonts A through Z and 0 to 9).

TextBox.Name: o
TextBox.Description: Name of the downloaded font to be substituted
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any name up to 8 characters.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FL
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FL command provides the ability to link any TrueType font, including private character fonts, to associated fonts.\r\nIf the base font does not have a glyph for the required character, the printer looks to the linked fonts for the glyph. The font links are user-definable. The font linking remains until the link is broken or the printer is turned off. To permanently save the font linking, use the ^JUS command.

TextBox.Name: f1
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any name up to 8 characters.

TextBox.Name: f2
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any name up to 8 characters.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^HT
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: This command is available only for printers with firmware version V60.14.x, V50.14.x, or later.\r\nThe ^HT command receives the complete list of font links over a communication port.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^LF
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: This command is available only for printers with firmware version V60.14.x, V50.14.x, or later.\r\nThe ^LF command prints out a list of the linked fonts.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FB
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FB command allows you to print text into a defined block type format.\r\nThis command formats an ^FD or ^SN string into a block of text using the origin, font, androtation specified for the text string. The ^FB command also contains an automatic word-wrap function.

NumericBox.Name: a
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: 0 to the width of the label in dots

NumericBox.Name: b
NumericBox.Description: Max. number of lines in text block

NumericBox.Name: c
NumericBox.Description: Add or delete space between lines

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FC
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FC command is used to set the clock-indicators (delimiters) and the clock mode for use with the Real-Time Clock hardware.\r\nThis command must be included within each label field command string each time the Real-Time Clock values are required within the field.

TextBox.Name: a
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any ASCII character.

TextBox.Name: b
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any ASCII character.

TextBox.Name: c
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any ASCII character.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FD
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FD command defines the data string for the field.\r\nThe field data can be any printable character except those used as command prefixes (^ and ~).

TextBox.Name: a
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any data string up to 3072 bytes.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FH
ZPLCommand.LongDesc:
The ^FH command allows you to enter the hexadecimal value for any character directly into the ^FD statement.
The ^FH command must precede each ^FD command that uses hexadecimals in its field.
Within the ^FD statement, the hexadecimal indicator must precede each hexadecimal value. The default hexadecimal indicator is _ (underscore).
There must be a minimum of two characters designated to follow the underscore. The a parameter can be added when a different hexadecimal indicator is needed.

TextBox.Name: a
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any character except current format and control prefix (^ and ~ by default).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FM
ZPLCommand.LongDesc:
The ^FM command allows you to control the placement of bar code symbols.
It designates field locations for the PDF417 (^B7) and MicroPDF417 (^BF) bar codes when the structured append capabilities are used. This allows printing multiple bar codes from the same set of text information.
The structured append capability is a way of extending the text printing capacity of both bar codes. If a string extends beyond what the data limitations of the bar code are, it can be printed as a series: 1 of 3, 2 of 3, 3 of 3. Scanners read the information and reconcile it into the original, unsegmented text.
The ^FM command triggers multiple bar code printing on the same label with ^B7 and ^BF only. When used with any other commands, it is ignored.

TextBox.Name: x1
TextBox.AcceptedValue: 0 to 32000 dots - e = exclude this bar code from printing.

TextBox.Name: y1
TextBox.AcceptedValue: 0 to 32000 dots - e = exclude this bar code from printing.

TextBox.Name: x2
TextBox.AcceptedValue: 0 to 32000 dots - e = exclude this bar code from printing.

TextBox.Name: y2
TextBox.AcceptedValue: 0 to 32000 dots - e = exclude this bar code from printing.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FN
ZPLCommand.LongDesc:
The ^FN command numbers the data fields.
This command is used in both ^DF (Store Format) and ^XF (Recall Format) commands.
In a stored format, use the ^FN command where you would normally use the ^FD (Field Data) command. In recalling the stored format, use ^FN in conjunction with the ^FD command.
The optional "a" parameter can be used with the KDU Plus to cause prompts to be displayed on the KDU unit. Also, when the Print on Label link is selected on the Directory page of ZebraLink enabled printers the field prompt displays.
The number of fields and data that can be stored is dependent in the available printer memory.

NumericBox.Description: Number to be assigned to the field

TextBox.Name: a
TextBox.AcceptedValue: 255 alphanumeric characters maximum (a-z,A-Z,1-9 and space).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FO
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FO command sets a field origin, relative to the label home (^LH) position.\r\n^FO sets the upper-left corner of the field area by defining points along the x-axis and y-axis independent of the rotation.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FP
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FP command allows vertical and reverse formatting of the font field, commonly used for printing Asian fonts.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FR
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FR command allows a field to appear as white over black or black over white. When printing a field and the ^FR command has been used, the color of the output is the reverse of its background.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FS
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FS command denotes the end of the field definition.\r\nAlternatively, ^FS command can also be issued as a single ASCII control code SI (Control-O, hexadecimal 0F).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FT
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FT command sets the field position, relative to the home position of the label designated by the ^LH command. The typesetting origin of the field is fixed with respect to the contents of the field and does not change with rotation.\r\nThe ^FT command is capable of concantination of fields.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FV
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: FV replaces the ^FD (field data) command in a label format when the field is variable.

TextBox.Name: a
TextBox.Description: Variable field data to be printed
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any data string up to 3072 bytes.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FW
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FW command sets the default orientation for all command fields that have an orientation (rotation) parameter and sets the default justification for all commands with a justification parameter. Fields can be rotated 0, 90, 180, or 270 degrees clockwise by using this command. Justification can be left, right, or auto.\r\nThe ^FW command affects only fields that follow it. Once you have issued a ^FW command, the setting is retained until you turn off the printer or send a new ^FW command to the printer.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^FX
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^FX command is useful when you want to add non-printing informational comments or statements within a label format. Any data after the ^FX command up to the next caret (^) or tilde (~) command does not have any effect on the label format. Therefore, you should avoid using the caret (^) or tilde (~) commands within the ^FX statement.

TextBox.Name: c
TextBox.AcceptedValue: Any data string.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^TB
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^TB command prints a text block with defined width and height.\r\nThe text block has an automatic word-wrap function. If the text exceeds the block height, the text is truncated. This command supports complex text layout features.\r\n^TB is the preferred command for printing fields or blocks of text, instead of ^FB.

NumericBox.Name: b
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From 1 to the width of the label in dots

NumericBox.Name: c
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From 1 to the width of the label in dots

ZPLCommand.Name: ^GB
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^GB command is used to draw boxes and lines as part of a label format.\r\nBoxes and lines are used to highlight important information, divide labels into distinct areas, or to improve the appearance of a label. The same format command is used for drawing either boxes or lines.

NumericBox.Name: w
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From value of t to 32000 in dots

NumericBox.Name: h
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From value of t to 32000 in dots

ZPLCommand.Name: ^GC
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^GC command produces a circle on the printed label.\r\nThe command parameters specify the diameter (width) of the circle, outline thickness, and color.\r\nThickness extends inward from the outline.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^GD
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^GD command produces a straight diagonal line on a label. This can be used in conjunction with other graphic commands to create a more complex figure.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^GE
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^GE command produces an ellipse in the label format.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^GF
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^GF command allows you to download graphic field data directly into the printer's bitmap storage area. This command follows the conventions for any other field, meaning a field orientation is included. The graphic field data can be placed at any location within the bitmap space.

TextBox.Name: e
TextBox.AcceptedValue: ASCII hexadecimal data: 00 to FF

ZPLCommand.Name: ^GS
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^GS command enables you to generate the registered trademark, copyright symbol, and other symbols.

ArrayOfZPLCommand.ZPLCommand:
^LH Label Label Home The ^LH command sets the label home position.\r\nThe default home position of a label is the upper-left corner (position 0,0 along the x and y axis). This is the axis reference point for labels. Any area below and to the right of this point is available for printing. The ^LH command changes this reference point. For instance, when working with preprinted labels, use this command to move the reference point below the preprinted area.\r\nThis command affects only fields that come after it. It is recommended to use ^LH as one of the first commands in the label format. ^LHx,y ^LH{{x}},{{y}} ^LH|x,y
>

ZPLCommand.Name: ^LL
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^LL command defines the length of the label. This command is necessary when using continuous media (media not divided into separate labels by gaps, spaces, notches, slots, or holes).\r\nTo affect the current label and be compatible with existing printers, ^LL must come before the first ^FS (Field Separator) command. Once you have issued ^LL, the etting is retained until you turn off the printer or send a new ^LL command.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^LR
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^LR command reverses the printing of all fields in the label format. It allows a field to appear as white over black or black over white.\r\nUsing the ^LR is identical to placing an ^FR command in all current and subsequent fields.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^LS
ZPLCommand.LongDesc:
The ^LS command allows for compatibility with Z-130 printer formats that are set for less than full label width. It is used to shift all field positions to the left so the same commands used on a Z-130 or Z-220 Printer can be used on other Zebra printers.
To determine the value for the ^LS command, use this formula:
Z-130 and Z-220 values for ^LHx + ^FOx
(distance from edge of label) = printer value for ^LSa

ZPLCommand.Name: ^LT
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^LT command moves the entire label format a maximum of 120 dot rows up or down from its current position, in relation to the top edge of the label. A negative value moves the format towards the top of the label; a positive value moves the format away from the top of the label.\r\nThis command can be used to fine-tune the position of the finished label without having to change any of the existing parameters.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^ML
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^ML command lets you adjust the maximum label length.

NumericBox.Name: a
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: the dpi of the printer multiplied by two, up to the maximum length of label

ZPLCommand.Name: ^MD
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^MD command adjusts the darkness relative to the current darkness setting.

NumericBox.Name: a
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From -30 to 30, depending on current value

ZPLCommand.Name: ^MN
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^MN command specifies the media type being used and the black mark offset in dots.

ComboBoxValues.ComboBoxValue: Auto-detects the type of media during calibration

ZPLCommand.Name: ^MT
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^MT command selects the type of media being used in the printer.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PF
ZPLCommand.ShortDesc: Slew Given Number of Dot Rows
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PF command causes the printer to slew labels (move labels at a high speed without printing) a specified number of dot rows from the bottom of the label.\r\nThis allows faster printing when the bottom portion of a label is blank.

NumericBox.Description: Number of dots rows to slew

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PH
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PH command causes the printer to feed one blank label.\r\nThe ^PH command feeds one blank label after the current format prints.

ZPLCommand.Name: ~PH
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ~PH command causes the printer to feed one blank label.\r\nThe ~PH command feeds one label after the format currently being printed is done or when the printer is placed in pause.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PM
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PM command prints the entire printable area of the label as a mirror image. This command flips the image from left to right.

ComboBox.Name: a
ComboBox.Description: Print mirror image of entire label

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PO
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PO command inverts the label format 180 degrees. The label appears to be printed upside down. If the original label contains commands such as ^LL, ^LS, ^LT and ^PF, the inverted label output is affected differently.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PP
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PP command is not immediate. Therefore, several labels might print before a pause is performed. This command pauses the printer after the current format prints.\r\nThe operation is identical to pressing PAUSE on the control panel of the printer. The printer remains paused until PAUSE is pressed or a ~PS (Print Start) command is sent to the printer.

ZPLCommand.Name: ~PP
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ~PP command stops printing after the current label is complete (if one is printing) and places the printer in Pause Mode.\r\nThe printer remains paused until PAUSE is pressed or a ~PS (Print Start) command is sent to the printer.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PQ
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PQ command gives control over several printing operations.\r\nIt controls the number of labels to print, the number of labels printed before printer pauses, and the number of replications of each serial number.

NumericBox.Name: q
NumericBox.Description: Total quantity of labels to print

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PR
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PR command determines the media and slew speed (feeding a blank label) during printing.\r\nThe printer operates with the selected speeds until the setting is reissued or the printer is turned off.\r\nThe print speed is application-specific. Because print quality is affected by media, ribbon, printing speeds, and printer operating modes, it is very important to run tests for your applications.

ZPLCommand.Name: ~PR
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ~PR command is supported only by the PAX and PAX2 series printers.\r\nIf the ~PR command is enabled (see ^JJ on page 255), the last label printed reprints, similar to the applicator asserting the Reprint signal on the applicator port.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PS
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ~PS command causes a printer in Pause Mode to resume printing. The operation is identical to pressing PAUSE on the control panel of the printer when the printer is already in Pause Mode.

ZPLCommand.Name: ^PW
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^PW command allows you to set the print width.

NumericBox.Name: a
NumericBox.AcceptedValue: From 2 to the width of the label in dots

ZPLCommand.Name: ^XA
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^XA command is used at the beginning of ZPL II code. It is the opening bracket and indicates the start of a new label format.\r\nThis command is substituted with a single ASCII control character STX (control-B, hexadecimal 02).

ZPLCommand.Name: ^XZ
ZPLCommand.LongDesc: The ^XZ command is the ending (closing) bracket. It indicates the end of a label format.\r\nWhen this command is received, a label prints. This command can also be issued as a single ASCII control character ETX (Control-C, hexadecimal 03).
